required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: High Flow Nasal Oxygen Versus Usual Care in COPD Pulmonary Rehabiliation
clinical_study.official_title: Comparing the Effect of High Flow Nasal Oxygen With Usual Care on Pulmonary Rehabilitation in COPD Patients After an Acute Exacerbation; a Pilot Randomized Controlled Trial

brief_summary.textblock: To compare the effects of high flow nasal oxygen with usual care during an outpatient 6-week pulmonary rehabilitation program after hospitalization for COPD exacerbation.

detailed_description.textblock: This is a pilot randomized controlled trial to compare the effects of high flow nasal oxygen with usual care during an outpatient 6-week pulmonary rehabilitation program after hospitalization for COPD exacerbation.

primary_outcome.description: It is the maximum distance walked in 6 minutes

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 3 weeks, 6 weeks and 1 month after completion of program
secondary_outcome.description: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease assessment test (CAT) score

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 3 weeks, 6 weeks and 1 month after completion of program
secondary_outcome.description: This scale has 2 subscale scores of 1) Depression 2) Anxiety. Scores of 0-7 = Normal, 8-10 = Borderline, 11-21 = Abnormal

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 3 weeks, 6 weeks and 1 month after completion of program
secondary_outcome.description: It is a test of respiratory function

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 3 weeks and 1 month after completion of program
secondary_outcome.description: It is the maximum distance walked in 6 minutes

arm_group.description: Patients will under go usual care ( pulmonary rehabilitation on room air or with nasal oxygen supplementation)
Patients will undergo pulmonary rehabilitation with high flow nasal oxygen

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Age 21 years and above
2. Known diagnosis of COPD based on history AND spirometry demonstrating post bronchodilator FEV1/FVC ratio <0.7
3. Currently admitted inpatient for an acute COPD exacerbation as the primary diagnosis
4. Fit to participate in exercise therapy as determined by both physician and physiotherapist
5. Has the mental capacity to follow instructions
6. Experience shortness of breath on exertion
7. Have decreased ability to carry out activities due to shortness of breath
8. Willing to participate in the exercise program
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Uncontrolled/ unstable medical conditions such as severe chronic heart failure that make exercise unsafe
2. Pulmonary disorder other than COPD
3. Physical conditions that preclude the ability to participate in exercise or may impair exercise performance.
